image.altText: A man is led away by corrections officers

items.synopsis: A 19-year-old charged over a crash that killed five teenagers south of Sydney last year pleads guilty in Picton Local Court.

image.altText: A black and white photo of an unseen woman holding up a hand to protect herself.

items.synopsis: Victims of sexual assault who go to trial in NSW are still being accused of lying in 95 per cent of cases, making the experience harrowing and contributing to ongoing rape myths and stereotypes, a report finds.

title.children: 95pc of sexual assault victims in NSW accused of lying in court, damning report finds

image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The 'goddess of chaos' COVID variant is making headlines, but it’s been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: A close shot of Mr Butler's face, looking serious.

items.synopsis: The opposition will no longer attempt to unwind the government's scheme to halve the cost of hundreds of medications, asking instead for the government to take its act of "good faith" as a chance to redesign the scheme.

title.children: Coalition withdraws attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme, asking for government to delay start date

image.altText: man stands with back to camera looking at streetscape

items.synopsis: Asylum seekers say they want to live with dignity and contribute to the country that has taken them in, but declining government assistance makes that impossible.

title.children: 'All I want from life is to live like a human being': Why Ali relies on kindness to eat each night

image.altText: A street sign reads Bean Street, with a police car on the road and police officer standing in front.

items.synopsis: Police were called to the Rockhampton address this morning, where two bodies were found.

title.children: Two bodies found in Rockhampton home, police declare crime scene

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines have stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why is China so keen to stop resupply ships reaching a dilapidated warship stuck on a South China Sea reef?

image.altText: A woman is working at her computer speaking on the phone and looking at a notebook she seems really busy

items.synopsis: The 3G network switch-off dates are looming. Telcos say Australia is ready for the transition to 4G and 5G, but some community members disagree.

image.altText: Eight people in colonial-era garb on a longboat at sea.

image.altText: A boy faces a teacher who is standing in front of a blackboard.

title.children: Damning report finds 'considerable gaps' between regional and metropolitan education in NSW

image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: A man in a blue vest and blue shirt holds his hands in the air, at a rally

items.synopsis: Ecuadorian presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio is fatally shot at a campaign event.

title.children: Ecuador presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio killed while campaigning

image.altText: A woman walks in a cat walk in the NIFA's

items.synopsis: Growing up far from the glitz and glamour of the fashion world, Lillardia Briggs-Houston never thought she'd be on a national stage because, while the world is taking notice of Australia's oldest design traditions, big barriers remain.

title.children: Acclaimed Indigenous designer Lillardia Briggs-Houston named NIFA's Fashion Designer of the Year

image.altText: Actors.

items.synopsis: In India, the Modi government is accused of waging a war on Bollywood and using it for party propaganda.

title.children: 'You have to suck up or shut up': The clampdown on Bollywood's unforgivable sin

image.altText: A female child star with a bob haircut, looks side-on to a camera with a vacant expression

items.synopsis: Lil Tay, whose real name is Claire Hope, made a name for herself by posting controversial but viral videos that involved a lot of profanity as well as designer clothes and luxury cars.

title.children: Child star Lil Tay, famed for controversial online videos, reportedly dies aged 14

image.altText: Police crouch over evidence behind crime scene tape.

items.synopsis: Detectives have identified a woman whose remains were located at a unit complex in Brisbane last year. The body of Tanya Lee Glover was found tightly wrapped, covered in bedding and hidden behind a brick wall.

title.children: Body found tightly wrapped and partially buried under Brisbane unit complex identified by police

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: A man holds a navy blue flag with white writing, standing behind police tape

items.synopsis: FBI agents shot the Utah man, who referred to himself as a "MAGA Trumper" and had posted online about plans to "clean the dust off the m24 sniper rifle", just hours before the US president was due to land in the state.

title.children: FBI shoots and kills man accused of threatening Joe Biden

image.altText: Dr Linda Iles, who has short brown hair and is wearing a red top, poses for a photo next to a microscope in a blue-lit room

items.synopsis: If pathologists start looking for CTE in the brains of domestic violence victims, will they find it? And what will it mean if they do?

title.children: A doctor discovered 'dementia in a punch-drunk wife' in 1990. Now, experts say we should be screening domestic violence victims

image.altText: Margot Robbie in a scene from Barbie, and Cillian Murphy in a scene from Oppenheimer.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The benchmark ASX 200 index of our 200 largest listed companies is +0.05% at 1230pm AEST, up +3.5 points to 7,341.3 points. There's a fair bit of movement... Particularly with a -6.3% slide for shares in Downer EDI and a 3.9% slump for shares in AGL, both of which reported poor financial results today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 flat after morning trade, Downer EDI and AGL fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Some less than stellar news for your household budgets if you have Disney+ in your streaming repertoire — its subscription fees are about to go up. Disney CEO Bob Iger was discussing the entertainment giant's quarterly results overnight, and announced that it would be hiking the price of its ad-free tier of the Disney+ streaming service by 27% — taking it to $US13.99 a month for those in the US. The price increase will take effect in the US from October 12, and is planning to roll out the higher subscription payments to its European customers from December. Meanwhile Disney is also going to introduce lower cost, ad-supported streaming plans to Canada, the UK and other European markets from November 1 at a lower price point. Cracking down on password-sharin g is also firmly in Disney's sights, with Iger saying they plan to roll out a strategy similar to what Netflix has recently unveiled "sometime in 2024". Right now Disney hasn't said whether the price increase will affect those of us here in Australia — but given the increases we've seen with other streaming services like Netflix and Spotify, it seems to be a matter of when it affects us, not if .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney+ subscription fees to rise in US and Europe

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More evidence that, after a year of relative resilience to higher interest rates, the Australian consumer has finally given up the ghost. ANZ monitors the spending made through its cards and merchant payment facilities (i.e. point-of-sale terminals) to get a near-real time pulse on consumer spending. There isn't much of one. Over the week to August 5, spending dived 8% compared with the same period a year earlier. Considering how much prices have risen for most things over that year, that is a huge fall in the volume of goods and services being purchased. As you can see, Aussies cut spending on almost everything, even staples like groceries. The only sector going up was entertainment, driven by a 95% jump in cinema spending as the Barbie movie and Oppenheimer opened at the same time, the so-called "Barbenheimer" effect. We're not even going out for meals or drinks anymore, with dining-out spending now below pre-pandemic levels in 2019. "The ongoing softness in ANZ-observed spending, alongside the weak ABS household spending indicator and negative retail volumes print, suggests the RBA's efforts to curb spending are working," note ANZ economists Madeline Dunk and Adelaide Timbrell. "Many households are facing a cashflow squeeze and are adjusting by curbing spending."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Barbenheimer sends Aussies to the cinema, but spending plunges elsewhere

children.content: More evidence that, after a year of relative resilience to higher interest rates, the Australian consumer has finally given up the ghost.
ANZ monitors the spending made through its cards and merchant payment facilities (i.e. point-of-sale terminals) to get a near-real time pulse on consumer spending.
There isn't much of one.
Over the week to August 5, spending dived 8% compared with the same period a year earlier.
Considering how much prices have risen for most things over that year, that is a huge fall in the volume of goods and services being purchased.

props.alt: Internal ANZ data reveals what Australians are cutting back on

(ANZ)
As you can see, Aussies cut spending on almost everything, even staples like groceries.
The only sector going up was entertainment, driven by a 95% jump in cinema spending as the Barbie movie and Oppenheimer opened at the same time, the so-called "Barbenheimer" effect.

props.alt: Australians cut spending in most areas of life at the start of this month

children.content: Australians cut spending in most areas of life at the start of this month

We're not even going out for meals or drinks anymore, with dining-out spending now below pre-pandemic levels in 2019.

(ANZ/Open Table)

"The ongoing softness in ANZ-observed spending, alongside the weak ABS household spending indicator and negative retail volumes print, suggests the RBA's efforts to curb spending are working," note ANZ economists Madeline Dunk and Adelaide Timbrell.
"Many households are facing a cashflow squeeze and are adjusting by curbing spending."

title.children: Hunter Valley cattle farmers consider destocking as drought settles in

But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week is looming as an important moment for Australian housing

image.altText: A man with grey hair and dark glasses stands on a street outside a large house and speaks into microphones labelled 7 and 10.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Radio's Kyle Sandilands found to have breached rules with homophobic mpox comments: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Radio shock jock Kyle Sandilands has breached decency rules when he made offensive comments about gay men and the mpox virus, Australia's communications regulator has found. In a segment of the Kyle and Jackie O program broadcast in August 2022, the controversial Sydney media personality "stereotyped gay men as irresponsible in regard to their sexual health", the Australian Communications and Media Authority ruled. It says Sandilands painted them as prime carriers of a virus that presented a danger to the community and did not deserve any sympathy or compassion. The 2022 outbreak of the virus formerly known as monkeypox, which caused more than 140 confirmed cases, was declared a communicable disease incident of national significance by the chief medical officer. ACMA chair Nerida O'Loughlin says Sandilands's comments were derisive and insulting and breached standards of decency expected by the public. "Although there was a basis at the time for a public discussion about mpox that involved reference to gay sexuality, the segment went beyond any acceptable standards by conveying that gay men were irresponsible, were a risk to the community and did not deserve any sympathy even when presenting for medical assistance," she says. In a submission to the investigation, broadcaster KIIS 106.5 argued the segment was intended to bring about awareness to the community of the public health risk of mpox, but conceded it contained "some unfavourable descriptions of those susceptible to the virus, being homosexual males". Reporting by AAP.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regulator finds radio host Kyle Sandilands breached rules with homophobic mpox comments

props.alt: A man with grey hair and dark glasses stands on a street outside a large house and speaks into microphones labelled 7 and 10.

children.content: (AAP: Mick Tsikas)
Radio shock jock Kyle Sandilands has
breached decency rules when he
made offensive comments about gay men and the mpox virus
, Australia's communications regulator has found.
In a segment of the Kyle and Jackie O program broadcast in August 2022, the controversial Sydney media personality
"stereotyped gay men as irresponsible in regard to their sexual health", the Australian Communications and Media Authority ruled.
It says Sandilands painted them as prime carriers of a virus that presented a danger to the community and did not deserve any sympathy or compassion.

The 2022 outbreak of the virus formerly known as monkeypox, which caused more than 140 confirmed cases, was declared a communicable disease incident of national significance by the chief medical officer.
ACMA chair Nerida O'Loughlin
says Sandilands's comments were derisive and insulting and breached standards of decency expected by the public.

"Although there was a basis at the time for a public discussion about mpox that involved reference to gay sexuality, the segment went beyond any acceptable standards by conveying that gay men were irresponsible, were a risk to the community and did not deserve any sympathy even when presenting for medical assistance," she says.
In a submission to the investigation,
broadcaster KIIS 106.5 argued the segment was intended to bring about awareness
to the community of the public health risk of mpox, but conceded it contained "some unfavourable descriptions of those susceptible to the virus, being homosexual males".
Reporting by AAP.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Ecuador President Guillermo Lasso says the murder of candidate Fernando Villavicencio will not go unpunished. He said Villavicenio was shot at a campaign event in Quito. "For his memory and his fight, I assure you that this crime will not remain unpunished," Lasso said on X, formerly known as Twitter. "Organised crime have gone very far, but all the weight of the law will fall on them." Lasso said he would host top security officials at an urgent meeting. Videos on social media purportedly from the campaign event showed people taking cover and screaming as gunfire sounded. You can keep reading this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ecuador presidential candidate Villavicencio shot and killed while campaigning

featuredLink.title: Ecuador presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio killed while campaigning

props.alt: A man in a blue puffer vest holds mic and campaigns on a stage

children.content: Ecuadorean presidential candidate Fernando Villavicencio
(Reuters: Karen Toro)
Ecuador President Guillermo Lasso says the murder of candidate Fernando Villavicencio will not go unpunished.
He said Villavicenio was shot at a campaign event in Quito.
"For his memory and his fight, I assure you that this crime will not remain unpunished," Lasso said on X,
formerly known as Twitter.
"Organised crime have gone very far, but all the weight of the law will fall on them."
Lasso said he would host top security officials at an urgent meeting.
Videos on social media purportedly from the campaign event showed people taking cover and screaming as gunfire sounded.
You can keep reading this story here:
